TopicTitle: Do you call it soda or pop?

Articles.Content:
It's simple.

Do you call it soda or pop?

Soda pop.

Or coke, usually coke because that's the only soda i normally drink.

Neither.

Where I live, we call them soft drinks.
Same. They're soft drinks, people.
Soft drinks, or fizzy drinks if you have to be more specific than that.
Soft drinks. Is it only Australia that calls then that?
carbonated beverage

I was born and raised in Pittsburgh, PA and we have a dialect/ vocabulary that's unique to us.

Explanation and translation examples from a similarly- afflicted "yinzer"

Best,

-Slashy

[edit] Oops! Forgot to mention; it's "pop". [/edit]

Edited August 31, 2014 by GoSlash27
Pop. This is in the Midlands.

Nope, not just Australia for "soft drinks." There's good data on this for the U.S.: Dialect Survey Maps (question #105). An older version of the map listed "soft drink" instead of other, and that was the response for about 1/4 of the people in both major cities I've lived in.
Despite living in Arkansas, I refuse to adopt the Southern term "coke" (Unless it is actually Coke) I prefer" soda.
A giant carbonated soda!

Sugar water.

That usually doesn't have enough rum in it.
Soda, It's a soda drink.
Soft drinks or mixers, depending on the context.
I called it pop for all my life, then I started calling my dad "pops" and the drink had to become soda.

In Hungary soda means carbonated water, and pop means music like Rihanna and Lady Gaga.

An interesting convergence on Arkansas vocabulary is that old people call every kind of sweet soft drink "Cola". Fanta is called "Yellow Cola". Probably because the first Western-style soft drink in Hungary was Cola.
I call it Dr. Pepper, 7Up, Shasta, Pepsi, or Ginger Ale. Because I refuse to drink any other soft drinks. anyone who drinks coca cola is a nerd and a theif and a commie

In N. Ireland, they are sometimes known as "minerals". Otherwise, soft drinks.

Soda is American, and pop is Enid Blyton (famed for writing fiction that was out of date at the time it was published).
I simply say "drink". If I need to be specific I'll call it by name.
Whatever the manufacturer named it, so sprite or 7up

Pop...wow....there's a term I haven't heard for years

We used to have these trucks that came round with glass bottles of "fizzy pop" and we'd hand back the empties for a discount.

Eeeeeee.....them were the days...........*nostalgic distant stare*

Pop...wow....there's a term I haven't heard for years

We used to have these trucks that came round with glass bottles of "fizzy pop" and we'd hand back the empties for a discount.

Eeeeeee.....them were the days...........*nostalgic distant stare*

How retro can we get? Ever experience the joy of bread & drippings sandwiches?

How retro can we get? Ever experience the joy of bread & drippings sandwiches?

Bread and Dripping!!

we used to dream of bread and dripping sandwiches!

If we were hungry We had to suck a piece of coal!

Edited August 31, 2014 by MartGonzo

Bread and Dripping!!

we used to dream of bread and dripping sandwiches!

If we were hungry We had to suck a piece of coal!

Coal? We had to make do with carefully-polished sheep droppings!

--

If we're not careful, this could go on for some time...

(I was actually serious about the bread and dripping sandwiches, BTW; it's what happens when you're fed by people who grew up during the Great Depression. But nevermind...)
